author: Emily Dickinson
title: There is another sky
paragraphs: Where not a frost has been
I hear the bright bee hum:

author: Emily Dickinson
title: If those I loved were lost
paragraphs: If those I loved were lost
The Crier's voice would tell me --
If those I loved were found
The bells of Ghent would ring --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: You love me -- you are sure
paragraphs: You love me -- you are sure --
I need not start -- you're sure --
When frightened -- home to Thee I run --
Be sure you're sure -- you know --
If you'll just tell me so --
Than when -- a little dull Balm grown --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Because I could not stop for Death --
paragraphs: Because I could not stop for Death --
The Carriage held but just Ourselves --
We slowly drove -- He knew no haste
My labor and my leisure too,
We passed the School, where Children strove
We passed the Fields of Gazing Grain --
The Dews drew quivering and chill --
We paused before a House that seemed
I first surmised the Horses' Heads

author: Emily Dickinson
title: To see the Summer Sky
paragraphs: Is Poetry, though never in a Book it lie --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Nobody knows this little Rose
paragraphs: Did I not take it from the ways
And lift it up to thee.
Only a Bee will miss it --
For such as thee to die!

author: Emily Dickinson
title: I'm Nobody! Who are you?
paragraphs: Then there's a pair of us!
Don't tell!  they'd advertise -- you know!
To tell one's name -- the livelong June --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: I have a Bird in spring
paragraphs: I have a Bird in spring

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Awake ye muses nine
paragraphs: Awake ye muses nine, sing me a strain divine,
Unwind the solemn twine, and tie my Valentine!
Oh the Earth was made for lovers, for damsel, and hopeless swain,
For sighing, and gentle whispering, and unity made of twain.
All things do go a courting, in earth, or sea, or air,
God hath made nothing single but thee in His world so fair!
The bride, and then the bridegroom, the two, and then the one,
Adam, and Eve, his consort, the moon, and then the sun
The life doth prove the precept, who obey shall happy be,
Who will not serve the sovereign, be hanged on fatal tree.
The high do seek the lowly, the great do seek the small,
None cannot find who seeketh, on this terrestrial ball
The bee doth court the flower, the flower his suit receives,
And they make merry wedding, whose guests are hundred leaves
The wind doth woo the branches, the branches they are won,
And the father fond demandeth the maiden for his son.
The storm doth walk the seashore humming a mournful tune,
The wave with eye so pensive, looketh to see the moon,
Their spirits meet together, they make their solemn vows,
No more he singeth mournful, her sadness she doth lose.
The worm doth woo the mortal, death claims a living bride,
Night unto day is married, morn unto eventide
Earth is a merry damsel, and heaven a knight so true,
And Earth is quite coquettish, and beseemeth in vain to sue.
Now to the application, to the reading of the roll,
To bringing thee to justice, and marshalling thy soul:
Thou art a human solo, a being cold, and lone,
Wilt have no kind companion, thou reap'st what thou hast sown.
Hast never silent hours, and minutes all too long,
And a deal of sad reflection, and wailing instead of song?
There's Sarah, and Eliza, and Emeline so fair,
And Harriet, and Susan, and she with curling hair!
Thine eyes are sadly blinded, but yet thou mayest see
Six true, and comely maidens sitting upon the tree
Approach that tree with caution, then up it boldly climb,
And seize the one thou lovest, nor care for space, or time!
Then bear her to the greenwood, and build for her a bower,
And give her what she asketh, jewel, or bird, or flower --
And bring the fife, and trumpet, and beat upon the drum --
And bid the world Goodmorrow, and go to glory home!

author: Emily Dickinson
title: If I should die,
paragraphs: If Birds should build as early
'Tis sweet to know that stocks will stand

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Snow flakes.
paragraphs: I counted till they danced so
And then I took a pencil
And then they grew so jolly
And ten of my once stately toes

author: Emily Dickinson
title: I heard a Fly buzz -- when I died
paragraphs: I heard a Fly buzz -- when I died --
Was like the Stillness in the Air --
The Eyes around -- had wrung them dry --
For that last Onset -- when the King
I willed my Keepsakes -- Signed away
And then the Windows failed -- and then
I could not see to see --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Success is counted sweetest
paragraphs: Not one of all the purple Host

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Her -- "last Poems"
paragraphs: Gushed too free for the Adoring --
On the Head too High to Crown --
Nought -- that We -- No Poet's Kinsman --
What, and if, Ourself a Bridegroom --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: 'Tis whiter than an Indian Pipe --
paragraphs: No stature has it, like a Fog
Nor any voice imply it here
A spirit -- how doth it accost --
Each one of us shall be --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Heart! We will forget him!
paragraphs: You may forget the warmth he gave --
When you have done, pray tell me

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Tell all the Truth but tell it slant --
paragraphs: Tell all the Truth but tell it slant --
Too bright for our infirm Delight
As Lightning to the Children eased

author: Emily Dickinson
title: "Sic transit gloria mundi"
paragraphs: When I am far from thee!
Three cheers, sir, for the gentleman
So shalt thou have a pippin
In case the wind should blow!
And tho' full many a morning,
The trumpet, sir, shall wake them,
In dreams I see them rise,
Will take his hat, and run!
Good bye, Sir, I am going
And when the hand that plucked it

author: Emily Dickinson
title: Sleep is supposed to be
paragraphs: That is the break of Day!

author: Emily Dickinson
title: The Soul selects her own Society
paragraphs: The Soul selects her own Society --
Unmoved -- she notes the Chariots -- pausing --
I've known her -- from an ample nation --
Then -- close the Valves of her attention --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: After great pain, a formal feeling comes
paragraphs: After great pain, a formal feeling comes --
The Nerves sit ceremonious, like Tombs --
The stiff Heart questions was it He, that bore,
Of Ground, or Air, or Ought --
A Quartz contentment, like a stone --
This is the Hour of Lead --
As Freezing persons, recollect the Snow --
First -- Chill -- then Stupor -- then the letting go --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: I felt a Funeral, in my Brain,
paragraphs: I felt a Funeral, in my Brain,
Kept treading -- treading -- till it seemed
And when they all were seated,
Kept beating -- beating -- till I thought
And then I heard them lift a Box
With those same Boots of Lead, again,
As all the Heavens were a Bell,
And I, and Silence, some strange Race
And then a Plank in Reason, broke,
And I dropped down, and down --
And hit a World, at every plunge,

author: Emily Dickinson
title: I started Early -- Took my Dog --
paragraphs: I started Early -- Took my Dog --
Came out to look at me --
And Frigates -- in the Upper Floor
Presuming Me to be a Mouse --
But no Man moved Me -- till the Tide
And past my Apron -- and my Belt --
And made as He would eat me up --
And He -- He followed -- close behind --
Upon my Ankle -- Then my Shoes
Until We met the Solid Town --
No One He seemed to know --
And bowing -- with a Mighty look --

author: Emily Dickinson
title: "Hope" is the thing with feathers
paragraphs: And sings the tune without the words --
And sweetest -- in the Gale -- is heard --
And sore must be the storm --
That could abash the little Bird
I've heard it in the chillest land --
It asked a crumb -- of Me.

author: Emily Dickinson
title: The feet of people walking home
paragraphs: The feet of people walking home
Til bye and bye these Bargemen
My figures fail to tell me
